extendedMetadata.name: Objective
extendedMetadata.value: LO: 5.1: Why did Americans resist parliamentary taxation?

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: FA Analyze 05 01

config.question: What caused the breakdown of political trust between the American colonists and their British rulers in the latter half of the eighteenth century, eventually culminating in the American Revolution?

choices.content: Provincial assemblies in America started expanding their authority over taxation.
The standard of living of white Americans was falling drastically.
King George III allowed the Whigs in Parliament to run the nation and its colonies.
The British Parliament insisted on the supremacy of Parliament.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Drawing on the work of John Locke, the English philosopher, American colonists insisted that God had given them certain natural and inalienable rights. These were stated in the Declaration of Independence. See L.O. 5.1 Why did Americans resist parliamentary taxation?

answer_2.response: Consider This: Drawing on the work of John Locke, the English philosopher, American colonists insisted that God had given them certain natural and inalienable rights. These were stated in the Declaration of Independence. See L.O. 5.1 Why did Americans resist parliamentary taxation?.
